Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.raw_text: Javins v. First Nat’l Realty Corp., 428 F.2d 1071 (D.C. Cir. 1970)
Javins v. First Nat\u2019l Realty Corp.,.proposition: Under Massachusetts common law, every residential tenant is entitled to the covenant of quiet enjoyment — that is, the right to possession and use of the leased premises without substantial interference by the landlord.

105 CMR 410.000 et seq. (Massachusetts S.raw_text: 105 CMR 410.000 et seq. (Massachusetts Sanitary Code: Minimum Standards of Fitness for Human Habitation)
105 CMR 410.000 et seq. (Massachusetts S.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment is breached where a landlord’s acts or omissions substantially interfere with the tenant’s use and enjoyment of the premises, including where conditions render the premises unsafe, unhealthy, or uninhabitable, or where the landlord refuses to correct dangerous or unhealthy conditions.

Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.proposition: Plaintiff relies on and incorporates by reference the following authorities as relevant to the legal standard for habitability, health and safety standards, and the landlord’s duties regarding sanitary and fitness standards:
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly adopts and defines an implied warranty of habitability in residential leases and ties it directly to health, safety, sanitary, and fitness standards. It instructs courts to look to housing codes and statutory minimum standards for ‘decent, safe and sanitary housing’ and focuses the breach inquiry on impacts to the tenant’s health and safety. Thus, it is squarely relevant authority for the legal standard of habitability and the landlord’s duties regarding sanitary and fitness conditions.
Hilder v. St. Peter, 478 A.2d 202 (Vt. 1.relevant_excerpt: “[W]e now hold expressly that in the rental of any residential dwelling unit an implied warranty exists in the lease… that the landlord will deliver over and maintain, throughout the period of the tenancy, premises that are safe, clean and fit for human habitation…. In determining whether there has been a breach of the implied warranty of habitability, the courts may first look to any relevant local or municipal housing code; they may also make reference to the minimum housing code standards enunciated in 24 V.S.A. § 5003(c)(1)-5003(c)(5). A substantial violation of an applicable housing code shall constitute prima facie evidence that there has been a breach of the warranty of habitability.”
